Award.AwardTitle: LSAMP Bridge to the Doctorate Cohort 11

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
In order to address the national need for the U.S. to remain globally competitive in Science Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM) disciplines, an infusion of an untapped pool of talented, creative, and intelligent students historically underrepresented in STEM who earn Ph.Ds. is needed. Jackson State University (JSU), a Historically Black University (HBCU), has a strong track record for preparing primarily African American graduate students in chemistry, mathematics, biology, environmental science, computer science, and engineering for STEM doctoral degrees. JSU's BD program to date has produced 20 Ph.D. graduates from underrepresented groups and 94 who were admitted into doctoral programs. Through their program, JSU has and will provide well-qualified and diverse faculty members for U.S. universities and colleges, as well as impact the number of scientists, mathematicians, and engineers holding the doctorate and entering the workforce.

Jackson State University will execute a BD program that is based upon challenging and rich research and academic experiences, the development and implementation of professional long term goals and objectives, the utilization of STEM summer research internships at targeted Ph.D. program institutions, and international research experiences. The objectives of their BD program fall into four categories: Research and Academics, Enrichment Activities, National and International Partnerships, and Evaluation and Student Tracking. These activities along with sufficient financial support from the LSAMP program, rigorous curricula, and committed mentoring will allow their BD program to continue to accelerate and increase the quality and number of students historically underrepresented in STEM entering the Ph.D. pipeline.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes Report

 

Mississippi Alliance for Minority Participation Bridge to Doctoral program at Jackson State University. LSM-AMP is one of the leading programs in the nation, contributing to the national goal of increasing the number of underrepresented minorities pursuing research careers in science, technology, and engineering and mathematics. The goal of the Bridge to the Doctorate (BD) program is to bridge LSAMP students who have received a baccalaureate and Masters degrees in a Science, Technology, Engineering or Mathematics (STEM) area into STEM doctoral programs and prepare them to excel in and complete those programs. Fellowships in the BD are provided for the first two years of graduate study through a grant received from the National Science Foundation. The objective of this grant is to broaden participation of underrepresented minority students in STEM disciplines. The program seeks to remove students' hesitancy about entering graduate school and fears of creating financial indebtedness.

 To date 45 PhD’s have been produced by the Mississippi alliance BD program and many more students are in the pipeline.

 

Cohort 1- 13 have proven to be very committed to completing the requirements of the program and to pursuing their terminal degrees.

 

ACCOMPLISHMENTS to DATE

 

Table 1:  Impact of BD Program for Cohorts 1-13

 

 

Past performance of the LSMAMP BD signifies its success in producing students who attain PhDs and the program’s potential to continue to achieve this goal. 

Table 1 summarizes the impact of the LSMAMP-BD Cohorts 1 through 13.   Table 1 also depics that a total of 143 students were admitted in Cohorts 1-13, and 120 have earned the MS degree. Of the 120 MS degree recipients, 119 were admitted into PhD programs, both at JSU and other universities nationwide. Currently, 45 BD Fellows have earned the PhD (Fig 1.), 12 are doctoral candidates, 37 are working on their coursework, while 10 dropped out of the PhD programs and joined the workforce. 83 % of the members of cohort 11 maintained a GPA of 3.0 or higher by end of their two year funding. Among those who maintained their required minimum GPA, 60 % maintained a GPA 3.4 and higher.

One of the most important activities of the LSMAMP-BD program is the Summer External Research Internship. This internship is undertaken during the summer between the first and second year of the program and lasts between 10 and 12 weeks. Students will present their summer research at symposia and conferences after they return to campus. Each student is placed with a research mentor at one of our many partner institutions or national laboratories. Effort is made to match the student with a mentor who is doing research that is a close match for the student's master program during the summer. Some of the students end up staying at that particular institution for the PhD program. Below are  placement out comes for Cohort 11.

 

Table 2: Student placements.

 

 Admission to PhD Programs

The disciplines of biology, chemistry and engineering have the highest share of PhD admission. The diversity in STEM background and doctoral field of study is higher as compared to previous cohort. For example, in cohort 11 two students are pursuing in PhD in mathematics and statistics, two areas that URM are highly underrepresented.

 

Table 3. Distribution of PhD Program by cohort
